Thank you for posting this, Iâ€™ve felt this often. Itâ€™s validating just to see all of these responses and advice and acknowledgment. Iâ€™m a psychiatric RN looking to become a psych NP. Itâ€™s helpful to know other providers feel this way, so that if/when I do as a provider, it wonâ€™t be unexpected or shameful.  What I would like to know is how do we find psychotherapy for those in the psychiatric field? I have such a hard time with that. What if our therapist is a colleague? What if we have mutual patients? Is there a way to get virtual therapy from someone out of state (/country) where there will be no professional overlap? I am constantly worried about this, how will I get myself help when Iâ€™m concerned about crossing professional and personal boundaries? My current therapist doesnâ€™t work with my patients but my psychiatrist does some moonlighting. We just donâ€™t look at each other at work. Itâ€™s awkward.

Heated blanket, heating pad, sauna, hot bath, yoga, stretching, walking. Lidocaine patches/icy hot. 

For headaches I take Motrin or Tylenol. Donâ€™t start with 800mg of Motrin as someone else said, start at 400 and work up if it doesnâ€™t work for you. Motrin can tear up your stomach (ulcers) when taken in high amounts. 800 is quite high. Iâ€™d recommend a lower dose and then alternate with Tylenol every 4 hours as needed.

Iâ€™m imagining your intentions are good here but you have some questionable beliefs about antidepressants. Some people need antidepressants and many or even most of them need to be on them for far more than 6 months. They donâ€™t even start working until a month in. Also- what antidepressant misuse are you talking about? You donâ€™t get a high or a low from antidepressants, they (if working for you) just help you feel â€œnormalâ€ and if they arenâ€™t working for you, you can feel the same or worse. SSRIs/SNRIs/MAOIs can be literally life saving to someone severely depressed or suicidal. Thereâ€™s no need to â€œrecommendâ€ weaning unless you are a doctor. 

OP- go to a psychiatrist or psych NP and talk about whatâ€™s going on. You donâ€™t have to take meds unless you want to but they can be highly effective. Follow professional advice about meds not internet people. Iâ€™m a psych RN for what itâ€™s worth.

That doesnâ€™t really sound like anything to do with PMDD. Itâ€™s more about anxiety, depression, and well, dysphoria, in the 14 (ish) days right before your period, suddenly stopping after the onset of your period.

If you have recently been diagnosed with a psychosis related disorder itâ€™s more likely that is your primary diagnosis, and then you also have PMS (which isnâ€™t unusual).

A lot of disorders that cause psychosis also cause ruminating thoughts, which sounds like what youâ€™re going through.

Talk to a psychiatrist first and foremost. It sounds like whatever else is going on might be more pressing, and you might need to change up your meds.

Source: am psych nurse

Can I give my advice? This is from my own personal experience, so no need to take it;

I am a first time mom. When I went into the hospital, I had one name I was pretty sure I would go with, but I wanted a long list of other names â€œjust in case it didnâ€™t suit herâ€. My husband liked a lot of names. 

When it came to the birth, I became EXTREMELY anxious about the name choice. All of a sudden I thought, â€œis X name the right name? Should I go with something else? Does she â€œlookâ€ like an X?â€ It was horrible. I was in choice paralysis. Not to mention being immediately post-partum I was filled with crazy changing hormones. I ended up picking a different name entirely the 3rd day i was there and felt completely rushed since the nurses kept telling me to fill* out the paperwork. 

My husband was no help because he just wanted me to be happy, and kept saying â€œwhatever you likeâ€- let me tell you, in that moment, I just needed him to pick one he liked so that I could be SURE we both liked it. I couldnâ€™t take the pressure of picking the â€œperfectâ€ name.

In the end, her name is her name now and I love it.

However, moving forward with future kids- Iâ€™m going into the hospital with one name picked out. I donâ€™t agree with the whole â€œyes but does the baby LOOK like that name?â€ question, because newborn babies donâ€™t even look like themselves 6 months later! My daughter looks completely different now than how she came out! 

Tl;dr - just pick one name and save yourself the anxiety of picking out a name when you are post-birth and full of hormone changes and needing a bunch of rest, not a huge decision to be placed on you.

Never let a patient get between you and the doorway. 

Never assume someoneâ€™s feelings.

Do read up on a personâ€™s history if you donâ€™t know them.

Do treat patients with respect and dignity (obviously, but some of my coworkers have a tendency to be very condescending..)

Itâ€™s probably a good idea to go over psych meds, at least know the classes of meds and what they do. Know Lithium levels.

Donâ€™t be afraid to say â€œI donâ€™t know the answer to that but Iâ€™ll find out for you.â€ Or.. â€œI donâ€™t know, let me ask the charge nurse.â€ When in doubt, deflect till later. You donâ€™t wanna give someone wrong information and have to backpedal. 

Good luck!
